data.title: Teenage kicks
data.meta_description:
Hi all, 

"Teenage Kicks" is a song by The Undertones, and I can't guess/understand what's the meaning of that expression. I copy below a part of the song...
data.text:
Hi all,

"Teenage Kicks" is a song by The Undertones, and I can't guess/understand what's the meaning of that expression. I copy below a part of the song for the context:

Are teenage dreams so hard to beat

Everytime she walks down the street

Another girl in the neighbourhood

Wish she was mine, she looks so good

I wanna hold her wanna hold her tight

Get teenage kicks right through the night

I think it could be something like "adolescentada" in spanish - although this is a non-existent word

Please, can you help me with this?

Cheers!

Hi Patrice

The expression "to get your kicks (out of something)" is to get extreme enjoyment/pleasure (out of/from that action).

for example,

"I get my kicks out of going to the cinema during the last showing when there is hardly anyone in the theater."

If you are familiar with the famous Route 66 in the USA, there is a song whose chorus is "I get my kicks from Route 66".

Hope this helps you!

So,

I can say "I get kicks of/from listening to music", can't I?

But... Can I say "I get kicks through listening to music"?

It sounds good but, is it correct?

Thanks a lot again!

Pat.
